>>2550878
In the Longhua district of Shenzhen in Guangdong China, you'll find Fysetc, Creality, Sculpfun, MINGDA, Boston Microfab, LDO Motors Co, Creatbot, Tenlog, Siboor, Anet, 3KU Technology, Anycubic, Creasee-3D, Malyan, Wanhao, and over 2 dozen other companies catering to the 3D printing market.

Malyan is one of the OEMs that creates the designs sold by Monoprice, Wanhao, and several others.
Wanhao Duplicator i3 / Monoprice Maker Select V2 started life as the Malyan M150 and later M160.
The Sainsmart Infi-20 is just a rebranded Malyan MA20.
The Monoprice Mini Delta is a Malyan M300.
The Maker Select Mini is Malyan's M200 lineup.

Anycubic takes bulk left-over B-Binned products and assembles and sells them as Creasee-3D.
So Creasee printers are dead cheap, usually coming with very old outdated aftermarket control boards (they still ship MKS Robin v1.2 boards from 2018) cheap clone Creality hotends, bent extrusions, flat v-wheels, shit like that.

The brands means nothing. Everyone uses the same parts from the same factories.
Some use binned parts, some sell the shit leftover from the other brands.
90% of 3D printers wordlwide are made in a 9 mile radius in Longhua, including many name-brand "legit" machines.
Longhua historically was a hotbed for PCB manufacturing, features some of China's oldest manufacturers of aluminum extrusions, and is adjacent to Shenzhen's largest silicon manufacturing district.

Any 3D printer brand with a Hong Kong address, check their certs. They put offices in Hong Kong, but they make their shit in a tiny circle in the Longhua district.
This is where your parts come from.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2550994
The ABL can compensate for it despite the single driver/dual-z setup, but it need to be set up right, which it isn't from the factory.
The setup is the same as countless printers from 8-10 years back, there are countless old single-driver dual-Z printers with ABL and no problems.

If the tilt of the gantry exceeds the typical +/- 2mm of bed leveling, you need to actually true the frame and moving assemblies of the printer.
Manually adjust your gantry so it's as level as possible with the frame of the printer, which means loosening ALL OF IT and tightening it up correctly when everything is actually aligned the way it should be.
If your bed is tilted relative to the frame, then it needs to be adjusted as well.
Don't measure from the bed surface, remove the bed surface and measure directly from the Y-Axis plate.
Only once the Y-Axis plate is level relative to the frame should you then install your build plate, and level it relative to the frame as well.
The Y-Axis plate can be adjusted the same way you do it on any old printer with Y-Axis rods and linear bearings, the mounts for the rods have significant play in them when loose and can be tightened in vaguely different positions, allowing for adjustment.

Always level each axis, the bed, and the x-gantry relative to the frame, NEVER to the bed. The bed is adjustable, moveable, and gets fucked with constantly.
ABL is for compensating for defects in the bed, it is NOT meant to compensate for poor tramming.
If you y-axis rods are level relative to the frame, and the x-gantry is level relative to the frame, and the bed is level relative to the frame, then you've got no tilt.
Your x-gantry can still tilt slightly in either direction when the z steppers are unpowered, but if it's set up correctly this tilt should never exceed ~0.04mm without you physically manipulating the z-axis leadscrews or pushing/pulling on the x-gantry.
If the motors are constantly going out of sync, one or both may be binding.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2551044
I run a 0.6 and Arachne on my big chink, it's a great setup. Arachne has been excellent, even the barely-implemented version in SuperSlicer 2.5.59.
It's not magic though, there is still significantly less detail than you get with a 0.4mm nozzle.
The biggest difference will be to people who already have shitty profiles and have to retune for Arachne thereby getting a good setup for the first time.
I already ran as low as 0.58mm up to 0.7mm line width with a 0.6mm nozzle, and now with Arachne I get widths of 0.51-0.7mm with my settings, not a massive change over the profiles I already ran.
As far as increased detail goes, I think it's overhyped as fuck, but Arachne is still great and totally worth using regardless of your nozzle size.
For high-detail models, it can potentially be much faster too if you set it up right and can take advantage of the gains. (If you're capped by volumetric flow, then Arachne ain't speeding up shit for you.)

>>2551289
I have a familiarity with and a distaste for how this happens in manufacturing, and how brands deliberately obfuscate things to make themselves appear more impressive, competitive, or just to drive fake competition.

You could start a 3D printing brand right now, order up custom printed PEI sheets and whatnot, custom printed packaging for generic unbranded stuff like springs, ptfe tube, etc.
You can order up stepper motors from LDO with your custom designed label and sticker on them.
You can start producing printers, by which I mean you can lightly modify one of the existing open-source designs and then send the design files and BOM to Malyan to have 'em produced for you, and put into the custom packaging you designed.
Want to sell control boards? Same story, lightly modify an existing opensource design and have it produced by an existing company with your logo on it.
If you make money off of it, you can hire someone to lightly revise the designs and keep them competitive with as little effort as possible.
Look at any electronics made by Fysetc, BigTreeTech, Makerbase, it's not so much a "pattern" as it is "blatant."

Easy example: https://github.com/ardyesp/ESPWebDAV
Fun, easy, opensource "hey look what I did."
That becomes this: https://www.fysetc.com/search?q=sd-wifi
Which is also this: https://biqu.equipment/products/bigtreetech-module-btt-tf-cloud-v1-0-sd-cloud-wireless-transmission-module
Similarly you have the ESP3D project: https://github.com/luc-github/ESP3D
BTT RRF Wifi Module, ESP8266 WiFi Transceiver Module, the ESP-01S variant for the SKR/Octopus, and their newer ESP-07S variant, Makerbase Robin WiFi Module, all adapted from the ESP3D project.

The ANET A8 was a generic Prusa i3 clone, and Prusa's i3 was a Mendel variant.
Some say the Ender 3 was an improved Prusa i3 clone, but that's absolutely not true, it's a derivative of other extrusion-frame printers like the Wilsons and Mendel Max (especially the Max 2).

>>2551460
>So building your own printer is the best move?
Totally a matter of opinion and personal experience. Nothing wrong with Chinese printers, some of them are sore dick deals for what you get.
Starting with an off-the-shelf chinkbox and modifying it as needed can be fun for some people, and certainly gets you very familiar with the machine.
If you want to build your own, there are great options and great resources to do it.
You can build a half-assed Voron with entirely Chinese shit and printed parts for <$500, or you can dump $4k into it and use the best bits and pieces out there, and as far as I'm concerned both options are worth every dime.

What's right for you is right for you.
If I needed another printer tomorrow, I'd be spending some serious cash to put together something better than anything I've got now.
If I ended up with an extra bedslinger frame like a stripped Ender, and I really wanted to deck it out and make it "good," >>2550503
If one of my siblings tells me they want a 3D printer and asks for recommendations, I'm going to pick up an $80 as-is returned Ender for them and fix it with the spares I have on hand.

What really matters is knowing the 3D printing is still a hobby, not consumer level.
Much like a tablesaw, plasma cutter, or a drill press, anyone can manage to do it, but actually taking advantage of it takes more knowledge and skill than you can glean from a user manual.
Starting with something affordable and abusing it until you know what you're doing and could actually make use of something better is a great way to go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2551555
Probably best to leave the micron-precise 3D printer and the router as seperate machines, huh.

>>2551559
I was looking at this a bit before. Compliant mechanisms where the 3D-printed spring bends along layer lines are possibly strong enough, but that generally means the spring is printed horizontally even though the mags are printed vertically, which looked like a pain to get printed properly. Plus it would have to be quite large in the scope of things, like a 3cm+ long spar with a nub on the end, and there's no guarantees that the nub would last a lot of cycles.

For my magazine latch I think I've decided on using a piece of spring-steel harvested from a vacuum cleaner retraction spring. Just needs to protrude from the magwell at an angle to catch on a small hollow in the mag itself. To release it, you either have a shim that's pushed between the spring and the mag, or something else to pull the spring-steel back away from the mag. Done well you could have the springiness of the release button come from the same piece of spring-steel, and still not have it fall out when not in use.

Would also be pretty doable to have a springy protrusion into the magazine that works like those spring-latch mechanisms This Old Tony machined in that one video. Using spring-steel instead of compliant printed plastic you'd glue a little printed follower on the end of the spring-steel, using a plastic spring you'd have to print it separately to have sufficient grain strength. Theoretically you'd only need a thin channel in the side of the mag for this to engage with, and could get away with a relatively long compliant spring for minimum plastic deformation.

Are you also making an edgy 18650 holder for your handheld electronics projects?

>>2551593
lmao i was literally doing this like two days ago for a sten mag.
I went with a paddle release since it's going to be more rigid than a printed side release. you could also try something like how a glock spring works. you push a button to move a bit of spring wire to the side.

it depends on the geometry of your magazine, how you want to do it. a sten mag has a slot cut in the back of it, so this lever would tilt forward and keep the magazine from coming down. you push the lever and the mag can drop free.
since you have that knob on the side, you could put a lever that engages underneath it.
i planned to hollow out a slot on the back of the lever, and put a torsion spring inside, pinned in place with a dowel pin which is also holding the lever. (spring drawn in red). basically like an AK mag release.
or, you could put a dimple on the lever and index a compression spring on it, like how a scorpion evo mag release works.
I just don't think a push button ar15-style mag release works well with plastic. i don't think it would have the rigidity with how thin it is.

>Be me, buy a [Prusa/Bambu] printer, ready to join the future.

Slicing tolerance isn't for correcting undersized or oversized prints.
Horizontal expansion can grow or shrink objects horizontally by a specified amount. You also have hole horz. expansion that works on holes only, not the whole model.
I use 0.15mm hole expansion for my ABS and that usually works well.

>>2552352
this is actually pretty good quality straight out of the box for a consumer FDM machine.

One thing to keep in mind is the printer is best at smooth bottom surfaces (on the print bed) and top surfaces (where it travels on the last layer), as opposed to walls and interiors, so you may want to align your parts with the critical features or faces there.

Another thing I used to do in this situation is use an acetone vapor chamber to smooth the print after it's done -- you can find lots of guides and videos for this online, it's super easy and doesn't require anything expensive or hard to find.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My design for a microphone cartridge. The identical green and yellow frame-halves clamp the membrane (circle cut from space blanket) within a full frame, while screwing the frame into the orange base pushes a ridge into the perimeter in order to apply tension. Similar design to an SLA printer's resin vat. The slots in the base are for grid wires to come from. The membrane wire will just be a thin piece of enamel wire clamped in the frame with the foil, if it messes with the fitment I can always file a small groove in one of the frame-halves to make it better, or add some aluminium foil to increase contact area as to not wear through the thin layer of metal on the space blanket. The outer holes are for elastic frame mounting.

I'll first try making it into an RF microphone using a CD4046 or two, that sounds fun. Though making it with a quality JFET instrumentation amplifier right on the cartridge would be better.

>>>2552719
Did you reset eeprom? It's easy to forget.
Good that you trammed the bed. The other major thing from the github seems to be:
>Go to Motion / Homing and select Auto Home. Watch the homing process. The X axis should go ALL the way to the left and bump up against the left side of the frame. The Y axis should go ALL the way to the back and bump into the back of the frame. If either of these don’t go all the way, or make grinding noises your sensitivity is too high or too low respectively. If you have an issue with the X axis not going all the way to the left your sensorless homing for the X is too sensitive. Likewise if it grinds loudly against the left side it is not sensitive enough. Go to Configuration / Advanced / TMC Drivers / Sensorless Homing. Go to the axis you need to tweak (X or Y). If your X axis stops before hitting the left side you are too sensitive on X. So lower the X value by 5 and retry homing. If your X grinds too much for instance on the left side, you are sensitive enough so raise the X value by 5. Use the same process for Y if it has issues. Once you tweak the values to your liking, be sure to save settings so they persist reboots.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2552822
What, seriously?
EXP3 was an excuse for them to jam the useful EXP1 and EXP2 bits in one place so they could make their RepRap12864 clone with only one cable instead of two.
The Creality "CR-10 Stock Display" is very well documented at this point.
BEEPER | BTN_ENC
BTN_EN1 | RESET
BTN_EN2 | LCD_PINS_D4
LCD_PINS_RS | LCD_PINS_ENABLE
GND | 5V
This is the original arrangement you'll see on the Melzi/Sanguino based Creality boards.
In recent applications the reset line is unused.

The EXP1 and EXP2 port were originally there to provide access to Aux header 3 and 4 on RAMPS boards, which includes shit we don't need for a normal CR10 display.
On Crealitys Melzi derived boards with the CR10 stock display, they moved all the stuff necessary for a typical LCD and rotary encoder into one place, one connector, and dropped the other unnecessary stuff for SD cards and whatnot.

If you want to do this, it's up to you to verify how your EXP port(s) are implemented in Marlin, in the corresponding pins file.
You may need to modify some of the assignments to work with a CR10 display, it's not uncommon for companies to rotate or flip these connections.
Either way, it's pretty easy, I've used a CR10 stock display on several different boards from BTT and MKS without trouble.
I've since moved on: >>2546567

It's thankfully not really any different than any other 12864 TFT with a ST7920 in SPI. The SPI is the important part, obviously these displays aren't set up for the parallel interface of the ST7920, SPI only.
It's fully supported with u8glib, it's very easy to work with like any other display, if you've ever hooked up an SPI display to an Arduino then it'll be extremely straightforward.
They're great inexpensive ready-to-use interfaces with easy mounting holes, screen, encoder, and buzzer/beeper built in that's easily swapped for a real speaker.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2552994
The P1P is meant to be competitive with ONE specific printer, the X1/C is definitely the fancy bitch.
The P1P gets you a well made and well designed frame and motion system that handles high speeds and high accelerations.
The hotend is excellent, not special really but it's a good hotend, and the P1P has all the same multimaterial capabilities as the X1/C.
Still uses the same autoleveling strain-gauge setup the X1/C uses, but without the LIDAR of course.

$700 to the US available right now, compare it to a Prusa at $1100 assembled or $800 for a kit.
Build Volume of the P1P 256 x 256 x 256 mm, Prusa 250 x 210 x 210 mm
Footprint a P1P 386 x 389 x 458 mm, Prusa 500×550×400 mm
Speeds are incomparable, motion systems are incomparable, the P1P is a true CoreXY system and the Prusa is an ancient bedslinger.
Wifi and Bluetooth out of the box, Prusa still gives you an 8bit control board from 2012.

Add 4-color printing to P1P: $350 for the AMS, you connect some bowden tubes and two electrical connectors.
Add 5-color printing to Prusa MK3S+: $300 for the MMU2S Kit, 171 step guide from Introduction to First Print / Haribo Time.
Step 6 of 171 notes that you might break the printed parts, and can just print new replacements if necessary. Encouraging.

$1050 gets you a solid multi-material printer that runs at impressive speeds, with Wi-Fi and Bluetooth.
With Prusa, $1100 - $1400 gets you a solid multi-material printer with an ancient 8 bit controller, printed components, a massive 171 step procedure to achieving multi-material status, and is ultimately incapable of running at even half the typical printing speeds of the P1P.

That's what the P1P is for, shitting on Prusa and their garbage value, that's very specifically why it exists.

>i try to be mindful of all the things that might otherwise end up in a landfill.

This is getting into a pretty broad topic but in a manufacturing context the purpose of 3d printing is that it allows for rapid iterations without punishing mistakes. I've been in situations where they find an obvious design flaw in the hull of a boat or something, but they already invested so much into tooling, that they're like "fuck it" and just decide to cover it up with stupid fixes. And if you look at the Wikipedia articles for like half the planes that exist, you'll see similar situations with fins and shit they added to make it recover from a spin. If you think your pile of printed boats is somehow making the problem worse and not better, you don't understand anything about manufacturing. Even setting aside the safety impacts, think about how much plastic bullshit people buy and how much people's value judgements are going to improve just by owning a printer. It's infinitesimal compared to the waste of shipping some injection-molded trinkets across an ocean. Not saying that we shouldn't consider the impacts, but the opposite, that the environmental impacts are more than surface-level and it can be a net improvement. Consumer fdm alone will not solve the problem, but it is a tool, and yes, the benchies are a tool too.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2553122
I dedicate an agonizing number of brain cycles to shit like this already, and benchies as a tool are fine, but largely this isn't what folks are doing.

I would wager that a majority of the benchies printed were done so just because it was the first or most popular thing at the top of thingiverse or printables or whatever. Or to see how fast they can be printed.

Most aren't printing boats to improve the the science of 3D printing, they're doing it to validate their choice of 3D printer. There are a great number of folks that stumble through the discord channels that i'm in to ask "how do i get my bambu to print that 2 nanosecond benchie lol"

For the folks that need to print tests over and over to perfect their craft so that they can sell a better product, they're printing their product. not more boats. Printing a 'one size fits all' plastic boat is exactly the kind of "well we invested 10k into this injection mold so we better use it" kind of thing we could have avoided from the start.

The only case I can really make for it is if you're trying to dial in settings for a specific material. At that point there are dozens of other tests you can use to uncover that information more quickly.

If a little boat is somehow the perfect test for your 3D printing enterprise then great. print more boats. but I bet it isn't and most people printing them probably don't even know what they're looking for.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2553385
>you have to spend minutes to hours scrolling
If you ask me this is preferable to klipper's handling of configs.
You can take a look at marlin's config file and you get a good idea of what the firmware can do. Everything is there and you have comments that give a bit of context in case it's not very clear what each setting does.
Now when setting up klipper, just like with marlin, you're going to start configuring based on templates made for your printer. Except only the bare minimum of settings are mentioned there so any additional functionality is not listed. You don't know if it can do abl, you don't know if it can do dual independent Z, you don't even know if it has thermal runaway. Of course, all of this is there, but you have to go digging through the scattered bits of documentation on github to begin to piece together what you're supposed to write in the config file to make it work.
And this is for features you want to enable. Klipper has a mountain of stuff that is enabled by default that's not listed in the config. For example, klipper's config reference page mentions that pausing a print is possible if you add [pause_resume] to the config. But there is no mention of the fact that there is a limit to how much the printer will wait. Only the reference docs on github will tell you. And that limit by default is 10 minutes, after which the klipper cancels the print job. So if you want to pause a print to insert some nuts or something else you might come to the printer and find a cold bed and an error message in octoprint if you don't do the job in those 10 minutes.
There's also a maximum extrusion volume per move. Again, shit not mentioned anywhere but on github. It is a calculated value based on nozzle size and some other factors. The standard value calculated for 0.4 nozzles is enough for printing with 0.4 and 0.6 nozzles, but with 0.8 it's easy to reach the limit. So klipper expects you to edit the config every time you change the nozzle.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2553137
Benchy is printed because it's a quick, simple, easily recognized, easily validated test. You can diagnose all of the most common printer issues from a Benchy. That's it.

It's also worth noting that while you are correct that most Benchies are not printed to advance the "art", speed printers mostly focus on Benchies and they shit out an astounding number of them. Last time I checked, the fastest Benchies are in the 2.5-3 minute range right now, and speed printers produce very many as they tweak and tune their machines. So they produce a disproportionate number of Benchies, and Benchies are being used by them to advance the speed of printing.

For example, speed printers these days don't have fans on the hot end. They instead have massively powerful fans mounted on the side supports to keep them in-line with the hotend, and have them blast air at the hotend, which has passive air ducts that guide the airflow onto the print, producing much higher net cooling while also lowering the mass of the hot end so it can zip around faster.

>>2553158
Octoprint + Bed Level Visualizer plugin is what I use.

>>2553462
Could be a few things. Sometimes it can look like that if the nozzle is too far off the print bed. Other times the problem will be your retraction settings.

Make sure your bed is level and if you have a z-probe, calibrate your z-offset. If those are good, try tweaking your retraction settings. Be careful not to increase retraction distance to the point that it pulls the filament back so far that it leaves the heat block, otherwise it might cool into a clog that can't be remelted because it can't get back to the heat block. That distance will vary by printer.

You might want to look up some guides or videos for your specific printer. "Stringing" is a key word to look for.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2553342
You can't avoid nubs. You can either lower the tip size for supports or clip them instead of pulling. Either way, you're going to need to sand, 1000 grit wet is what I use. Emery cloth is good too since it's more flexible, always sand wet. If they are indents, you can fill them back up with a very very light coat of resin mixed with talc and then cure it. Just be careful you don't overdo it and turn your print into a blobby mess.

Of course, you should be orienting your prints so that the most visible parts have no supports attached- I'm not sure you would even need supports with that print in the correct orientation.

>>2548445
I like bed frames that don't move
That usually means the sides and bottom run to the floor to support the platform

Bending and movement have more to do with leverages than material. If you have an 8" tall pine frame connected with tighten-able connectors at the top and bottom of each corner joint, that frame isn't going to flex whereas a steel frame made of angle iron only attached with a single line welds will bend

Same thing goes in reverse- a steel box frame made with 2"x3" heavy gauge u-channels attached with tall L brackets will outlast a wood frame with flimsy connectors

Steel. I mean, honestly, bed frames aren't going to break. My last bed frame was over 30 years old, it was a cheap, nasty thing that had an extra box underneath you could slide out for an extra bed. Never failed, all softwood and cardboard construction.

Only reason I replaced it is because I wanted a higher frame so I could fit more shit under it in a small room.

I had to support a bedframe bought by a retard because they didn't check the weight specs. I essentially just took out the existing slats, and replaced them with 2x4s, with an extra leg in the middle that went down to the floor, so the weight of the fat retard went directly into the floor while the bed frame just stabilised it. Haven't had any problems with it in 5 years or so, cost about 40 bucks in materials. Could've added more legs so it was totally free floating, but I didn't see the point.

Assuming your frame is rated for your weight, you're not going to break it if you don't start jumping on the bed. What's far more important is your mattress, and modern mattresses are made like dogshit.

>>2548090

>tradesman of 10 years.

The answer is complex. Some trades, there is simply no way to do them without damaging your body. Drywall is a perfect example. You can't make drywall healthy, it just isn't good for your shoulders, your neck or back. But some trades you can make healthy IF you practice good body mechanics AND you don't put in too many hours a week.

I do remodeling, and I AT MOST put in 30 hours of labor a week. The rest is bidding jobs, picking up supplies, etc.

And to help out with my body I:
> practice good body mechanics
> stretch 30 min a day
> drink lots of water
> see a chiropractor
> see a massage therapist

Also with any trade you should very quickly either start your own company, or move up into management with the company you are with.

If you are someones bitch and you have been at it for over 2 years, then you fucking up big time.

I’m a commercial metal framer and shitrock hanger (aka Carpenter). If you are lifting board all day on the ground you will easily destroy your back and knees if you aren’t taking care of yourself on a daily basis. I’m an installer so I’m usually resting a large amount of the board weight onto a lift. 12x4 sheets of abuse board are absolute dogshit to lift off a board cart. Not to mention all the other shit you have to transport around and up stairs. Not to mention hazardous shit you have to expose yourself to. I got monokote in my eye before and had to get it removed at the doctors, I’ve inhaled an insane amount of brown death insulation packing walls. I’ve been around retard masons cutting block putting dust up everywhere. I’ve literally watched labors dump garbage cans full of concrete dust into hoppers and directly inhale the cloud of toxic silica. I take care of myself and love the work I do but it’s definitely not for everyone. And I haven’t even mentioned the insane drug addicts/Alcoholics you will come across working in construction. Definitely not for everyone and if you work around dickheads and their cocksucking dipshit friends you will not have a good time. Union or not, always find a good outfit of people you can work well with. Finding that is almost priceless and word of mouth and personal connections are pretty much what get you work in my trade. a lot of people are confused by the topic, so allow me to explain it. in america, we use a grounded system for our transmission and distribution of electricity. the power company literally drives a 8-10ft copper ground rod into the ground, and attaches a wire from it to the neutral on the transformer. this gives stray currents a path back to source.
for wiring in a building, we use equipment grounding conductors to clear ground faults. a ground fault is when a metal part (such as a metal chassis or conduit or water pipe etc) is energized. the equipment grounding conductor provides a low resistance path back to the panel, and allows very high amperage to flow through the circuit breaker, which induces a very strong magnetic field, causing it to trip, thus cutting the power to the metal, which is no longer a threat to personnel.
in your picture, you have a series circuit. the white wire is not a neutral as in a 120v circuit, but rather an ungrounded conductor connected to one leg of your service. by code, it is supposed to be reidentified, but that wasnt common practice until recently and inspectors may choose not to enforce it.
you have 2 equipment grounding conductors because one leads back to the panel to clear fault paths, and one comes from the well pump so that if there is a fault with it, it can also be cleared.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2550788
A lot of replies in this thread have no idea what they're talking about, and the entire conversation about "ground" is a side-topic at best.

Your 2 current-carrying conductors are both oscillating 120v sine wave. Both of these waves "center" around what your powerplant/home considers "zero volts" - which is also the potential of your system's ground, by design. However, the two waves are 1/120sec or 180° out of phase with *each other*, so one is at +110v at the same time the other is at -110. This makes their difference measured on a multimeter, 220.

Why are the colors confusing? Your pump/switch manufacturer or electrician has used single-phase theee-wire cable for a phase-to-phase 240V installation, probably to save money. So the "neutral" wire in the jacket isn't actually neutral... current flows back and forth between the two insulated wires like a swing or seesaw. Ideally it won't travel to the ground at all - if it does, your circuit breaker or GFCI will probably trip.

The reason the ground is connected to the box body like that instead of straight thru is to protect you in case one of the hot wires becomes frayed/pulled and makes contact with the metal box... This would give it 120V relative to your floor and the other grounded metals in your pump and room, making a potential shock hazard. With the ground wire connected there, that voltage could run along the copper wire to powerplant ground, instead of your body.

You are describing nuclear reactions, not alternating current. You are an idiot. Generating electricity does not alter the number of electrons in the outer valence shell. Every time an electron is stripped from an atom, it is simultaneously replaced by another electron returning to the source. To the source. The source. Source. Also, source. Yes, source. Back to source. A thousand times, source. An electron in the loop of current returns to the source. Electrical reaction. Not nuclear reaction.
If we could just use a few volts to shift around the number of electrons of an atom, we would have as much heavy water as we could possibly want. But the electron is always replaced. There is always a complete circuit.
If there isn't a complete circuit, you can rely on I in the formula P=IxE to remain zero because electrons aren't moving. Sure, voltage is present but no current. This means no power. That's why your light switch can shut off power usage. Since turning off a light switch turns off a light instead of creating new radioactive isotopes in your walls, you really need to rethink your position.

This is the answer. An angle grinder is, in my opinion, very rarely the best tool for the job. When you use them for things they *are* the best tool for the job for (removing mill scale from steel with a flap disk, for example) they are relatively safe. Cutoff wheels are genuinely dangerous and I will go to great lengths to not use one. Get yourself a die grinder for small work and a proper set of saws for larger stuff. >>2545623
>It's happened to me a few times

Sounds like excessive pressure. Quality discs like Pferd and SAIT (I buy boxes from the local welding supply or online) hold up very well. I let the disc float and maintain control, and importantly I rock it forward and backward in the plane of rotation to avoid binding like the industrial abrasive cutoff saw I used at my first job.

I prefer 6" grinders for the reach, easy control and edge speed, and modded the guards on my 4-1/2" cordless grinders to 6" by variously buying a 6" guard and removing the internal nubs (DeWalt) or cutting and welding (Makita, Milwaukee) to combine their mounts with 6" guard shells. Works great.

posts.com: How do i make it so a door will naturally stay ajar if i leave it open? This particular door will slowly creep open all the way, but I'd like its "at rest" position to only be like 7 inches open. Is there a way to do this without using a door stopper?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2546044
There are spring hinges that automatically close the door, hinges that hold the door open when it swings past 85° and some that do both, but none that I know of that let you set the hold point with the door mostly closed.
There may be a hydraulic closer that lets you do this, screen door closers usually have a simple stop on the push rod that you can set to stay open at any point, but if you try to force them closed it can damage them.
Easiest way to do what you want is to tweak one (or more) tab/ear thingy(s) on a hinge just enough out of alignment with its mates that driving the pin back in makes it spring back into alignment; that tension will eventually cause the door to stay where you leave it. The tradeoff is that the hinges will likely squeal, it's hard to dial in the forces precisely, and it makes pulling the pins a lot harder when you need to remove the door.
But it does work (at least until wear lowers the tension), and is an old door hanger trick to "fix" doors that open and close by themselves because their jambs or the walls the jambs are installed in are out of plumb in the front-to-back direction.

Easy hydrogen sulfide gas generator:
you will need:
1. iron powder
2. sulfur powder
3. some sort of acid (hydrochloric, acetic, sulfuric)
(Optional) 4. Ammonia cleaner

Mix the iron and sulfur powder together until they are a fine, uniform mixture. Put the powder on some sort of stone you don't care about, and light it. This reaction gets very hot, something like thermite, and will melt through metal, so be careful and do it outdoors. Once it has cooled, chip and scrape off whatever pieces of the result that you can. This is iron sulfide. Mixing iron sulfide with an acid will produce hydrogen sulfide gas, which is responsible for the smell of rotten eggs. You can hide a bottle acid in the ceiling, drop the FeS chunks in, and run away, or you can go the optional, slower release route. Make the hydrogen sulfide, and bubble it through the ammonia solution. This will create ammonium sulfide, which degrades back to hydrogen sulfide over time. You can put this liquid in a bottle and set it up to slowly drip over time, releasing hydrogen sulfide as it drips. As >>2548488 said, this gas, being a sulfur compound, is toxic, and is around the same level as hydrogen cyanide gas. Hydrogen sulfide has a very obnoxious odor at low concentrations, but at high concentrations, it burns out your sense of smell and you can't smell it anymore. The dangerous concentration of the gas is past this point, so if you can smell it, you're fine, if not, too much. Good luck, and don't hurt anyone if you do this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2550254
This works for me but I have ducks. Cost around $500 one year ago. Customizing it was a lot of trial and error, but now its quite functional. Whatever you do, make it tall enough so you can easily get inside with a rake, pitchfork, and shovel. Don’t staple the wire mesh because birds will eat staples off the ground (I lost one for this reason).
-autofill water valve ran from underground sprinkler line
-wingnut cleanout cap, use dryer vent drill attachment to clean
-a weeks worth of food in the feeder
-cheap vinyl on floor of nesting box for easy cleaning
-battery powered automatic door opens at sunrise so I can get hammered and sleep in on weekends. Closes at sunset.
-mesh cloth on top of run so coons can’t climb in
-chicken wire underneath gravel so nothing can dig its way in
-I got smart halfway into summer and poured concrete in the feeding area because they drink, eat, and poop all at the same time lol. The flies were insane and it was nasty af. Concrete solved everything, now I just spray it off once a week.
-put straw on the ground for warmth and nesting and stuff. They love it.
-Lowe’s sells green accordion style R1 foamboard. Folds up for easy storage. I wrapped the entire run with it this winter.

>>2551973
This.
Was the fence his, yours, or did it reasonably belong to both of you?
If you're not required by law to have a fence established between your properties, then the fence is just a fence, and if you want fence you buy fence.
Fence laws are way less common than people think, fences are a luxury that at one time were uncommon for builders to install.
If you wanted a fence between your house and the one next to it, wanted some nicely defined borders, you pulled out the plans for your property and threw up a fence at the edge.
Now people take it for granted, probably because suburbs and teeny-tiny properties with teeny-tiny yards; hell now they make a point of when they don't build a fence "COMMUNAL YARD AREA - SOCIALIZE WITH THE NEIGHBORHOOD WHETHER YOU LIKE IT OR NOT."

If you didn't sit down and agree on a fence plan with your neighbor, then you went and replaced a bunch of fence on your own dime, sounds like the problem is solved and you did it yourself.
It'd be very hard to argue otherwise unless your neighbor is actually obligated to have helped; if he has livestock that he wasn't interested in fencing properly, that could be a good place to start.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2548526
Again, this is by no means an archival or reference binding. It's not supposed to protect the contents over a hundred years, (i.e. the solvent in the glue leeches across the gutter to the print over decades.) It also becomes brittle over time and excessive (reference) use, (i.e. the spine can crack and the block splits.)
Think about old paperback books that you get for a dollar or at a garage sale. Not the family bible.
It's also important to set it properly. Too cold or not enough time and the binding can drop pages which weren't sufficiently adhered.
But all things considered, the process today is pretty good. The solvents are better and less leeching. The glue stays more flexible longer. Even office paper has gotten better for it -- ironically by getting worse (more proportion of recycled material in the paper makes it more absorptive.)
The process is certainly good enough for a use case where you have the material in a other form and you just want something to hold while you read it a few times, maybe give it to a friend, and otherwise leave it on a shelf in case you want to pick it up again years down the line, until your heirs either give them away or throw them away.
And even though it's somewhat more expensive at bit under a dollar per binding strip, it's better than staples. (No catching on your fingers, no weird signature folds, no tearing, no rusting, etc.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Yes, just about any starting metal can be drawn and fullered to improve grain structure. This is how raw cast billets from a steel mill are improved before being rolled into final form. Just watch a video on the steelmaking process, and you'll see the first step after casting is to use a giant press or power hammer to lightly squish the billet from different sides.
